newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Austria's Vranitzky says neutrality will stay.
newsitem.headline: Austria's Vranitzky says neutrality will stay.

text.p: Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky said on Wednesday he saw an active role for Austria in the economic and political future of the European Union, but that his country's 41-year neutrality would not be compromised.
"Austria has a full and important role to play in the EU," he told a news conference after a meeting with European Commission President Jacques Santer.
But asked how far Austria was prepared to go to agree to proposals for more EU cooperation in defence, he said: "Our status of neutrality will not change".

Austria is a member of the Partnership for Peace, which links the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and former Eastern bloc countries -- and also has observer status within the Western European Union (WEU), the future defence arm of the EU.
Vranitzky said, however, that these links -- along with Austria's participation in peacekeeping forces in Cyprus and Bosnia -- did not affect neutrality.
The EU is debating closer defence links as part of the inter-governmental conference (IGC), the EU's reworking of its treaties,
Negotiators have been considering amending the treaties to involve the EU, using the WEU, in peacekeeping and humanitarian missions.
Finland and Sweden, which along with Ireland make up the bloc's other neutrals, have promoted this idea. Vranitzky was non-commital about the plan.
Austria, perched on the former Cold War border between the feuding Eastern and Western blocs, has been neutral since 1955, when it drew up its post-World War Two constitution.

The Soviet Union, which occupied Austria after the war with allies Britain, France and the United States, demanded Austria enshrine neutrality as a central pillar of its national charter before it agreed to withdraw its troops.
